div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE PASSING OF THE SHAH
div.p: The long-expected death of the "King of Kingshas at last taken place. His Majesty's life, which had been artificially sustained for the past month, has now ebbed away, and Muzafter ed Din is no more. The eyes of the whole world will now be turned towards Persia, which for European diplomacy will be the centre of the greatest interest. Notwithstanding the assurance contained in oar telegrams of yesterday, that Great Britain and Persia, who are the Powers most interested, have agreed on a common policy to bo followed on the demise of the Bhah, this event may not improbably bring about a crisis in the Middle Eastern questioned nothing it more likely than that a break-up .of the Persian Empire may begin. It is in Persia that a great struggle for political supremacy will one day he fought, a struggle that cannot be confined to Persia, but mûst 'nevitably spread until its over-widening circles embrace Arabia, Mesopotamia, Anatolia and the whole Turkish Empire. It is a clear conception of this fact that has directed the course of European diplomacy of late years. Germany, while leaving nothing undone that could tend to strengthen her position in the Near East, has been straining every nerve to extend her influence in the Middle East. The commercial advantages which she hopes to derive from the Baghdad railway are, in the eyes of ihe German Emperor, of very secondary importance in comparison with the political interests which its completion would further. As a commercial venture the Baghdad railway for years and years after its construction must remain a very precarious investment; as a political instrument for the extension of German influence in Asia its value is inestimable. Thus Germany is not only directly interested in tho fate of Persia,but is already actively forging weapons designed to assure her political, commercial and industrial predominance there. England, however, is not sitting idle while the Kaiser is wording to realize his pet project of a railway from Hamburg to the Peipi&n Gulf, one of the elements in his vast ambitions regarding Asia Minor and Persia. She has rendered impossible without her direct participation any prolongation of tho Baghdad railway to an essential terminus on the Persian Gulf. She has established a friendly understanding with France which has withstood two severe tests, one in Morocco, when Great Britain loyally supported France, the other in the Tabah frontier dispute, when France loyally supported Great Britain. And she has laid the bases of a reconciliation with Russia, without which a friendly solution of the Persian problem is impossible. For Russia is really' the mistress of the Persian situation. From the military standpoint, her troops control the northern frontier of the Empire, and from the political standpoint financial operations on a colossal scale and big loans to tho Shah have made her the Power behind the throne in the Empire itself. So long as Muxaffer ed Din was alive no change in the situation was possible. But now that he is dead? Will his suooeseor acquiesce in the existing régime, will he be content to reign and let an other power rule t "That is the question." If he should become enmeshed in the intrigues of the European Powers, his advent to the throne may mark the beginning of one of the biggest diplomatic ooofiiets known to history.

div.p: Oar Keneh Correspondent writes : Pnoumonio Clagoe has made its appearanoe at Keneb. he disease was introduced to the town by a man soffaring from the disease who came from Nsg-Hamadi to visit a relative who resides here. After one day's stay the man died. The sanitary iffioer at onoe isolated 35 people who live in the neighbourhood of the deoeased's house. It is 1 oped no further cases will oooor io the towo owiog to the strict measures taken by Dr. Hastings and his men in disinfeoting bouses. div.head: ENGLISH FOR MIXED COURTS.
div.p: As long ago as 1899, at the suggestion of Loid Cromer, Mr. M. Belief, at that time President ot the Mixed Coart of Appeal, sent a oiroolar to the Presidents of the Mixed Coarts of Cairo, Alexandria, and Mansourah, notifying them that when recruiting the staff of the Courts preference should be given to those oaodidatea who bad a knowledge of the English language. With the exoeption of Port Said, where an English-speaking functionary was appointed to the judioial delegation, the suggestion fell through chiefly because no Englishman woold accept service in the Mixed Courts at the low rate of stipend allowed. ID view of Great Britain's position in Egypt, the indignity no less than inconvenience caused by the Courts not being "English spoken," is notorious. It if a matter for theBritishChamber of Commeroe to orge, once more, upon the attention of those whose interests are thus involved; and we hope with better results than ast time.

div.head: TRÀMWAYS IN KHARTOUM.
div.p: That nothing sacoeeds like soooess is amply illustrated by the history of the tramways in Khartoum. In his report for 1904 the Governor of the Khartoum Province writes
The steam tramways started *on March 5, 1904. At first (although crowded when ron for trial fire trips) the pnblio did not take to them. The takings for 28 days in Maroh were £8. 37.533.''

The Governor might have added, says the "Sudan Times," that at the time no sangain» hopes were entertained by the poblio as to the ultimate success of this ventare, and not oue siogte merchant in Khartonm would have been willing to ran the tramway on hisowo aoooont. But in the Sudan as well as in other oouotiies the soooess of suoh schemes depends upon the need of the poblio and the adequacy of the means used to meet it. Tbe need existed there and it required someone to supply it cheaply and regularly. Thus an end was put to the diffioolty of crossing the distance between Khartonm and the Mogren.

div.head:
ACCESION DAY
CELEBRATIONS AT PORT SAID
div.p: Oar Port Baid Correspondent writes : — On the anniversary of the aooession of H. H. the Khedive, H. B. the Governor of Poit Said held an official reception at the Gonvernorat which was «attended by the Government offi oial*, consnTs, and a large number of notables of Port 8aid. Io the afternoon his Bxoellenoy gave an <AtHome"toa largeand distinguished gathering.

There was an abundant display of flags in the town, and at sunset several houses were illuminated. Tbe Goavernorat was one mass of Japanese lanterns and fairy lamps and presented a very fine appearanoe.

In the evening a banquet was given by the Governor to 24 guests, who inolnded all the Consuls and Government officials, with the exception of 8now Bey and the Portognese Consol, the former having being called away on argent basiness.

Oar Fayoam Correspondent writes that the Moudir, Mohamed Mahmoud Bey, held a reoeption on Aooeasion Day which was attended by the ulema, officials, European residents, and notables. The celebration ended by the firing of the osaal sainte.
The following aooount of the Aooession Day celebrations in Cairo was delayed in transmission:—

One 'Accession Day is very like its predecessor, and the amount of last year's festivities in Cairo might very easily stand for those of yesterday. The same flags have been hung from the same hotels, and the same deoorations and illuminations have lined the streets. The same fantasias have been in progress in the Esbekieh Gardens. The same maguifioently uniformed 'soldiers and officials have been hurrying to and from the vioe-regal presence ; and aftet nightfall the same crowd perambulated the streets gasiog in stolid wonder at the same marvela they wondered at jast a year ago.

The road to Abbassieh in the afternoon was filled with the usual medlty of pedestrians and carriages all harrying to take up their positions round the vast dasty parade groand where H.H. the Khedive was to hold hiî annual review of his troops. Mansfield Pasha and his myrmidons were as usual on the spot to marshal the orowd into its apportioned plaoea and to mete ont justice to offenders against the common peace and order. Motor cars and carriages rolled into their respective enclosures, pedestrians gained whatever ooics of vantage remained open to them, andtroops took cp their acoostomed places and dnsted themselves with aoonstomed sangfroid jast as they did in other years. There was the usual wait before H. H. the Khedive, wi'h his escort of Lanoers and his reticue, arrived upon the soene and rode down the lines upon his proudly stepping steed. Onoe more he took up his place beneath the blood-red standard while his bands played and troops passed by saluting. First, the well appointed Lanoers, then the field gans and mole battery, after them the oadet corps and the varions regiments of infantry, Wheeling ronnd at the farther end of the ground they returned onoe more in oloser formation with standards fifing, then the Lancers and artillery paised at the trot and finally at the gallop, loud applause following them as they thundered by through the dust. On the conclusion of the manœuvres the troops re-furmed in long line across the gioond to receive the usual words of commendatiou from their sovereign, they in their turn signalising their loyalty and devotion in the costomary shoot from down the ranks, The entire proceedings lasted little oyer half an hour, H. E. the Khedive leaving agsiu with his esporf io the direotion of Koubbeh, while the troops, beaded by tfcei? bands, disputed tq &eir respective quarters. Qdo6 more the road became a seething mass of vehioies and humanity ; and onoe more Cairo was gained with an extraordinary absence of untoward sQoidents,

div.head:
THE SERVANT QUESTION IN EGYPT.
OLD RESIDENT'S SUGGESTION
div.p: "An Old Resident" (Cairo) writes : —May I be allowed to ventilate through your oolomns a grievanoe from which the whple community of European residents in Egypt are more or less sufferers, vis., the relations existing between themselves and their native servante Y It there in Egypt any family, or even any individual, whose life has not been made wretohed by the condoot of his servante At some time or another 1 Do we not all know the story of a suffragi engaged one day aod tamed away io a short time after a period of sufferiog and di'comtort resulting from the incompetence or misoondnot of the servant 1 Unfortunately the servant question touohes more foroibly the humbler and less affinent members of the EatopeaD community, as naturally the wages offered by them are less than Ihoqe given by their wealthier neighbours, and teoy can only look for servants in the teoond or third ranks and oannot afford io be too oritioal of the charaoter ot an applioànt I use the word "aufortonately" ot design because I believe that if the more important members of the commuDity, and eapeoially the highest class of officials, could be forced to suffer the same disoomforts as their humbler brethren, a way would be found to pnt an end to, or at least to mitigate, the present unhappy state of affairs.

I do not donbt that the offioial answer to any complaint will be that nothing oan be done, or we may be told that there exists a registry for servants. That any registry in the proper sense of the term really exists, I deny. There is an Anthropometrioal Bareau where aooased persons are measured and photographed, and where it oan be ascertained theft or other offencea. Personally, I myself wonld never dream of asking a presumably respeotable candidate for domestio service to submit himself to the humiliating ordeal ot being photographed and measured and examined to tiod out if he ii a ooovioted criminal, and I have never engaged any, out of numberless servants, with the certificate of the Anthropometrioal Bareau. Only one or two of the many applicants I have interviewed, and these the most inferior specimens of their olass, have been provided with the oertifioate.

And now-. I come to the main parpose of my letter, which is to soggest that the Government be petitioned to establish an offioial registry of native servants similar to that adopted in some parts of Burope. if others of your subscribers would help to advooate my Boggestion, and if your own infl lence could bo brought to bear in support of if, something mi^ht be done and a widespread expretaion of opinion on the part of the British aod other European residents might indnoe the high officials with whom rests the power to introdooe the continental system. Under this system every servant most be registered at a central office a- d an entry is made on every ocoasion of his taking or leaving a situation, a complete record of his career being kept from the moment he first enters domestio service. At present in Egypt there is no means ot trsoing the past history of an applicant for service beyond the written charaoters which he may think fit to produoe. There is no méausof knowing how many times

div.head: CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.
div.p: Amongst other exoellent bargains now offering on the Cairo Laud Exohange is that of the so-called "Garden City," an estate situate in the most fashionable quarter of Cairo: the Kasr Bl-Donbara. This property, oovering 400.000 sq metres, lying next to the residence of Lord Cromer, was bought from several Khédivial Princes in the winter of 1905 6, by the Nile Land Co. The position is unique, between the Nile and tbq tramway to Old Cairo, and it extends from the British Agenoy to Rodah Bridge. It is admirably parcelled oat into plots of 500 metres and upwards, minus, say, 120,000 sq. metres for roads and pnblio gardens. The ohief attraction of this land is the faot that no bailding erected thereon may oconpy more than two-thirds the area of the p'ot, so that eaoh house will have a garden ot its owu. Moreover, no business establishments whatever will be allowed exoept on those sites faoing the tramway. The most BtriDgent regulations have been made regarding bnilding here as it is desired to make this the most aristooratio quarter of Cairo. As an enoouragement to artistio architecture the Nile Land Co. are to distribate £50,000 amongst the bnilders of the 12 handsomest villas and the three handsomest frontages facing the Kaar-El Aini read, the competition to take place in 19C9 and the amount to be prid in tbe same year. It is here that the Rilz Hotels Oo. have selected a site for their hotel. Within the last few months about 150,000 lq. metres have been sold at pricer ranging from L.B. 8 to L.E. 15, but quite lately the price rose to L.R. 20, and it is expected that still higher figures will be reached, especially when all the land is sold.

div.head:
MOTORS IN THE DESERT.
OUSTING THE CAMEL.
div.p: The Mining Department of the Pinanoe Ministry is making considerable progress with its system of roads in the Eastern Desert. The road from Bdfoo to Bee* has been completed, and consiats of an excellent track ninety miles in length. From Beta it will biforoate to the Sontb and North. The southern branch of the road will go through the erne raid fields, while the northern extension will join the Keneb-Kosseir road from the Nile Valley to the Red Sea. Keneb is another base for a road northwards. This road is now being made aloDg the old Roman way, which was ooostrnoted in order tP bring the porpheiy from the Red Sea ooast to the Nile, where it was floated dowa tbe river to be taken to Rome, where it still forms snoh a splendid and prominent feature in many of the remains of the paiaoea and temples ot the Imperial epooh. This road,, as at present planned, is to end at Ghattar, which is ninety miles from Keoeb, and is half way to Gebel Zeit. Tbe Edfou-Bezt road has been largely used for motoring, aod the new type of motors, which have been specially built for the use of the Department of Mines, has been found very satit faotory for desert work. Motors are a far less costly and diffi- onlt meaLs of conveyanoe than oamels. The longest day's run in the Eastern Desert was made last midsummer, when 148 miles were traversed in one day. There is no comparison with the rate of the oamel Doring the last trip of the Mining Department's trioar (No. 2) 243 miles were accomplished in four days spent in the ordinary work of ^rspqot- ing roads and mines. The following details of the work aooomplished by two trioars and - - « - the motor oyole daring their journeys in the
if a would be servant hujeen sentenced for Eastern Desert are of considerable interest
as abowiog with what eoonomy motoring is praotioabte io the deaert:

Trioar No. 1, 6 h.p. Total mileage covered, 2,280 ; average miles per gallon petroleum, 25; average lobrioant per 100 miles, pints, 1.6 ; total cost per mile, including repairs, maintenance, spare parts renewed (but not inoloding depreciation),millièmes 22.87.

Trioar No. 2, 9 h.p. Total mileage, 1,051 ; average miles per gallon petroleum, 25.8; average lobrioant per 100 miles, pinte, 2.4 ; total ooet per mile repair, maintenance, spare part renewals, allowing for depreciation in tyre, millièmes 13 34. (millièmes S.S. not allowing for depreciation).
Motorbioyole. Total mileage, 1,462; average miles per gallon petroleum, 63.8 ; average lubrioaut per 100 miles, pints 0.35. Total cost per mile, millièmes 22.2

The tytes consist of ordinary pneamatio tyres protected by suitable leather and iron- studded bands. It hM been found that the three-wheeled motor oars are far more suitable for desert travelling than the motor oyoles, as the latter oaoce a great deal of strain to the rider. Water is not neoessary for motoring exoept at intervals of fifty miles.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: We would draw the attention of our readers to the advertisement of the farther issue, at per, of 235,143 shares in the Corporation of Western Egypt, Limited, which appears in another column of to-day's issue. Of the capital of £500,000, divided into 500,000 shares of £1 eaob, only 264,857 have been issued, and the remaining shares are now offered for snbsorip tion. This farihir oapital is required in order to complete the Western Oases Railway, now being construoted from the point of its con- neotion with the Egyptian State Railway at Khargeh Jonction (between Aboa Tjeht&nd Parshont) toKhargeh in the Oasis of Khargebl a distance of about 120 miles (=194 kilo metres) ; and in order to enable the Corporation to bring into fall cultivation and into a state of readiness for sale, simultaneously with the active mineral exploitation and develop ment, the extensive lands of the Oases to be acquired in virtue of the concessions. The land after reclamation will be sold either immediately or after holding for a period for enhancement in vaine, and the entire purchase moneys will be reoeived by the Corporation, Taking a very conservative estimate, an average profit of at least £10 per feddan, equivalent to a profit of £200,000 on eaoh of the 30 annnal grants of 20,000 feddans, is to be anticipated after the ocmpletion of the railway when the Corporation is placed in a position to prooeed with sales, and the shares of the company may be reoommended as a very sate and profitable investment. The subscription list was opened to-day at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, and will be olosed at or before 4 p.m. on Monday, the 14th inst.

div.head: TELEGRAMS
DEATH OF THE SHAW
CROWN PRINCE ACKNOWLEDGED RULER.
div.p: The Shah died at 11 olook last night. (22.)
London, January 9.
Sir E. Grey telegraphed to the Pertian Court and Government through Sir C. A. Spring Rice the King's and Government's condolencer.
(Reuter)
Teheran, January 9.

The h^ir apparent arrived at the Palace at 9 o'clock this morning, and was acknowledged Shah by the Grand V zier, Ministers, Princes and others. The Diplomatic Corps will be received by the Grand Vizier tomorrow for condolences, and on Sunday by the Shih for congratulations. The date of the enthronement has been fixed for 2nd February. (Reuter)
Ao official telegram whioh arrived at the Persian Consulate, Alexandria, last night confirmed the news of the death of the Shah.

Mozaffar ed-din was 53 years of age, and has ruled fur oyer tea yearsi His dynasty is comparatively modern, for it dates from 1791, when the great great-grand uncle of the late Shah obtained the Crown after a civil war which lasted fifeeen years, and founded the dynasty of the Kajàra, of which there have been five sovereigns. Prom his fifth year Mocaffir ed-din livèd in Tabris as Wali Ahd, or Heir Apparent. As he was not beloved by his father, Nil-r-ed din, be was appointed Governor of the Province of Az?ibijan, on the Russian frontier. The fntnre monarch was for the most part fortnnate in having excellent teachers, who neglected nothing in order to make him worthy to role one day over the people of Sadi, Hafiz, and Firdoci. Before be bad attained his twentieth year the Heir Apparent knew not only the old national language of Iran bat also Kurdish, Tarkish, and Arabio ; and there is probably at this momsnt in the Bast no soholar who was the late Shah's eqaal in his knowledge of anoient Oriental literature. In the interpretation of the Korar, one of the most important subject* of Oriental ednoation, the Shah was a master, and his personal opinions on disputed points have long been held in the greatest esteem, Five times daily the Shah observed the abln ticras and prayers ordained by the saored book, Moreover, be never tasted wine or any other form of alooholio beverage, and this an wonted abstemiousness was all the more to his oredit, as the inj inotion uttered by the Koran on this point is certainly very little observed by the Persians. Many songs in praise of wine, are to be found in the works of the Persian poets, for the Anaoreontio singers of Iran do not confine their odes to extolling the soent of the rose and the song of the nightingale. However, in this respeot the Shah felt bound to set a good example.

Mnziffar ed-din devoted special attention to pbilosophioal studies, and he was probably the only roler who took a delight in reading Plato and Aristotle. Modern philosophy in tin form of the "System of Mouode" by Leibnitz, and of Kant's "Categories," was also a favourite study. The little qoart at Tabris had quite a medieval aspect, for it «as thronged by poets, learned men, and philosophers ; and, in addition totbe pleasure* of the chase, it was the late Shah's favonrite pastime to disonss with these men the existence and object of ail things visible and invisible. Moreover, Mozifiar-ed din was a keen astronome? ; he spoke Frenoh fiaently, and read all the beat works written in that language. On his accession to the Throne the Shah informed the Chief Priest, or ImAm, of Teheran that his chief task would be to govern his people quietly and peaoefally with, the aid of the Almighty. It weald be too long a task to speoiiy the varions innovations intro* duoed and the methods of reorganisation set on foot by the Shah do ring the ten years of his role. That the Shah's measures have been well direoted is seen in the faot that he abolished eight thousand superfluous official posts, and diminished hfe Civil List by 150,000 krans, or about £>,625. More espeoi*lly were the people of Persia affected by his publication of an Edict of ToleratioD,by the abolition of the ssttled system of leasing the taxer, by making better provision for the varions pilgrimages undertaken by the people, by giving a oertain amount of Bell government to the towns, by the recent grant of a Constitution, and by reorganising the army on Bnropean methods.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
HIS ATTITUDE TOWARDS THE OCCUPATION.
div.p: The following is an extract from an artiole, contributed by Mr. Bdward'Dicey, C.B., to the "Empire Review"

As a persistent advocate of a British Pro* tectoratatove? E;ypt, I hold, as I have alwayi held, that England, in her own interest, mast be the paramount Power in the Valley of the Nile, and this conviotion nece?sarily involves the admission that the Khédivial Government mast be subordinate to that of the British Government. And I am convinced that the reigning Khedive realises this neoeaaity On the other hand, I fail to follow wbat I take to be the view of the 1 Times," that the Prince should necessarily be expeoted to remain grateful, to England for hav:ng deprived him or the inflaenœ and authority which, up to the time of onr military oocupation, appertained to the holder of the Khédivial throne. Happily for Bogland, for Egypt, end for himself, h:a Highiieaa is fully aware that in exiting conditions he moat come eff the worst in any eff art he may make tVemaneipate himself from the tutelage of the British Protectorate. Whatever his merits or demerits may be, he is a very intelligent and long-headed Priuoe ; and it is on that aooount I am unable to aoderstand how—pending evidence to the contrary —he should ever have associated himself with the Nationalist programme. Whatever else he may be, the Khedive is lord and master of the Palace party, supposing snch a body to have any existence in reality, and he knows Egypt far too well not to be aware that even if be wished to give any moral support or, still more, any pecuniary as-Htanoe to the Nationalist agitation, the faot woald be com- uaunioated at onoe to the British authorities in Egypt

In the earlier years of his Khedivate he did undoubtedly make an attempt to assert his commaod over the Anglo Egyptian army, bat the failare of bis attempt was not of a kind to enoonrage any repetition of an anti- British policy. Sinoe the collapse of his is- sertion that he was still master of his own troops, he has, in as far as I am aware, aeqQiesaed in the present system ander whieh he remains »hs raler of Egypt de jure, while Lord Cromer, as reprsseotativa of England, remains the raler dt facto. 8inoe the Anglo* Frenoh Agrrement, Abbas II. has realised the plain faot that be his lost the sopport of the one Power which could poedhly have assisted him in throwing off the yoke of Eogland. On the oooasion of the Saltan's attempt to reissert his olaims in the Sinai Peninrole, be supported-the rights of B^ypt, and, if I am oorreotly informed, wrote a des* patch to the Saltan, at Lord Cromer's instance, declaring th»t, in the event < ( Tetksy trying to alter the lines of demarcation between the Oitom in Empire and the Vassal State, his troops woald j >in with tbs British in repelling any act of aggression. If this be so, it seems incredible that, within a few weeks, he should have embarked on an insame attempt to overthrow the British military oo- onpation by an alliance with the Nationalist party.

Concerning the charge of having raised money by selling titles and decoration , it hardly needs refutation. A stranger does not require forty years or forty months or forty weeks' residence in Egypt not to be aware that from time immemorial titles and deooratioos were paid for either in me»l or malt, that is, by servioes rendered or by backsheesh. Even in England at the present day similar rewards are not infrequently the result of payments to " party '' purposes. I hardly compreheod, then, why wbat is regarded as a legitimate transaction, in England shoald be denoanoed as disgr*oefol in Egypt Again, neither the " Times " nor its correspondent seem to ba aware that Egypt possesses no decorations of her own, aod by her convention with Turkey hasa right only toalimited number of Turkish orders, suohaa the Otmanli and the Medjidi, Of this limited camber by by far the largest proportion are appropriated the British Agency as rewards for British effi rials in the Khédivial service, who, in Lord Cromer's opinion, have done good work in Egypt,

As to posts of emolomaot, the Khedive has no means of selling these to any would be purchasers, even if he was so minded. The disposal of all snol^ posts rests with Lord Cromer and Lurd Cromer alone. His lordship's patronage is exercised most conscientiously, and, from his own point of view, most wisely. Every candidate for (ffice well knows that the Dot of his nomination or rt commendation by tha Khedive would be rather detrimental than otherwise to the chanoe of his application being favonrably reoeived at the Briti h Agency.

div.head: EGYPT AND STONEHENGE
div.p: Little connection apparently exists between tbeiwftiteoto of tljq magp tuples in the Nile Valley and the rude Druidioal monuments in 8alisbnry Plain, yet in this book the author gives tha remits of inve*tig%tipus .carried ppt. at 8tcpebgoge and other places in England and Sootlapd, and shows that those who erected, these stone monument* oriented them with sojae precision by means of a*fj> nomioal chaervatians, probably obtained from Egypt. A similar study of some Egypti*u temples in 1891 had oanvinced him tba*- the same was done by ibe ancient Egyptians as described in the "Dawn of Astronomy,'' published in 1894 ; and be„DQw urges that the procedure in Britain was derived from that of Egypt.

After referring to the. aptronomtpal diviaion qf the year into four, seasons by thp^sj^ipes and the eqaiooxe* SirNorm«mLocky*r pe*8* to the agrioaltgrel division of tJhq year as determined' by vegt^ipn, apd distinguishes on*. y®4* beginning in May, the season of flowering, and another in whioh harvest time,

| August, was the first month. Besides these the solstitial year, beginning in Joue at the 1 summer solstice, is also rapognized, bat is ' considered to be ol later introdnotion. A 1 namber of stone cirplpe end other monuments have therefore been examined in order . to see whether there is evidence of the orienta- ! tion of their principal axes to sunrise on | the new year's day of these different years. Stonehenge is first described, and the or^en- ! tation of. its principal axis to the rising bud

at tha summer solstice was determined by a \ series of observations from whiob it was found . that the original orientation differed from ' tba azimnth of the risiug son at the sommer solstice at the present time. This durance I is asoribed to the slow, change in the obli- qaity of the eolipfio ; and on this basis the date of laying ont the axip is determined, as being 1680 B c, or, allowing for varions sources of error, the date of constfuotion is placed between 1900 and 1500 b.c.

Following this observational portion of the book is a sammarZ'd account of th^ folklore connejted with these circles, and with sacred trees, wells, and streams. As a result of this investigation the conolnsion is arrived at that, the earliest form of worship in Britain was that of the son on the most important dates of the May year, and subsequently of tha solstitial ! year ; and it. is maintained that this worship probably came from Egypt, where th'i rising and setting points on the.horizon of stars were ' employed, fiat in Egypt observations were not confined to the horizon, and the nght hoars were detorhrned by tha meridian passage if stare. Sir Norman Lockyor has produced a most interesting work dealing with a special point in arohmilogy, and rightly lays stress on the aoonraoy necessary in determining the orientation of the axes of anoient strnotnres. It was certainly the practice in eome oases to lay ont Egyptian temples by aligning «he axis on a heaveply body, though whether it was so universally done at eaoh extension or modifi oation of the bnildipg as the author has maintained is more donbtfal. A temple direoted ta the plaoe of solstitial annrise may have been intentionally so placed ; but in the oase of others which are held to be directed to the plaoe of a oertain star's rising.a degree of cantion is desirable, since tbs oase of Lnxjr Templr, on which the author lays espeoi*l stress, is open to another explanation, Sir Norman Lookyer considers that the three axes of this temple show a gradual shift necessitated by the preces* sional movement of the star to which th^y weie direoted.
In viewofthe amount of evidence conneotihg early worship with the lanria* it is not surprise

1 g that special oars shoald have been taken to mark the direotioo in which the son woald appear, and this ooald be don* with considerable aoonraoy, especially in the teqiples of Egypt. Here the series of rooms and courts with conneotiog doorways furnish a means for testing tbeories of orientation very saperior to that which it available in stone oiroles of mooh rader construction. It is therefore anfortnnate that when these temples were investigated less toon rate methods of observation were employed than tor the British stone oiroles, ths azimoths being determined with reference to the magnetic meridian, a single value for the declination throughout Egypt being nsed,whi'e the height of the horison was not always determined with preoision. In the oases taken as instances of stellar orientation it may happen that local considérations inflaenced the position of the baildingi and the oase of Luxor temple shows the need for canfion in this rMpeot. Borcbardt ha* recently shown by a detailed stndy of the temple that the first change of axis was in order to connect th* new extension of the temple with ap avenue < f sphinxes whioh led from Karoak. On the farther enlargement of the temple another shift was oansfd by building along tbe line of ths avenne which passed close to a small ekjsting temple erected by Thohmes III. whieh probably wés still in use. Wheo this amount of doubt ean oooor in the oa*e of a temple bating a clevly defined axi", the fullest evidence ie oeaestary with oiroles in which any number of axes are deter* minable.
div.note: 'gtonohettge and Other British Stono Monuments Astronomically Considered. By Sir Norma* Lockyor, K.C.Bl, F.R.S. (Macmillan. 10*. net).

div.head: St. Vitas' Victims.
div.p: Disordered Nerves in Children Culminate in St. Vitus' Dance.
A Ledbury Boy Affhctol Twitching, Restless, Emaciated. RestqrW te. BnlfW.iAdtte Boyhood.
A Splendid Nerve Cure found In
DR. WILLIAM'S PINK PILLS.
A common remark that children have no nerves is grievously incorreot, for the modern

at an early age. A ca«6 in point is afforded by the 8 yeir old son of Mr* Lawrence, of Portland- plaoc, Ledbury, Herefordshire, who «: flared from acute nervous disorders that onlmiuated in 8t. Vitus' Dance ; no treatment alleviated the little one's misery nntil in Dr. Williams' Pink Pills a comple e and j ermaueut care was fonnd.
"Two years age," said Mrs. Lawrence, "my son BtM1. b*gtyn.,to. b'ink, bis .eye* twitch
bis month id a strange manner. We tbonght it was only a silly habit at firpt. bot the symptoms git worse at^d ho was confinually blinking.or screwing bis f»ce up and twitobing his fingers. It was
Painful to bs qsar the Child.

I was told that it wan his nerves that tronbled him, and souipapeçial mediqipa was given to him, bot no r.-me lies bad any lasting effect, and in the eud he woald relapse as bad as ever, nntjl we a'ipo't gave up in despeh. Besides these involuntary m-veu.euta, E«fart looked extremely ill and puuy. div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Orders have been issued for recruiting foi the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, now at Cairo, to ba limited to men not under twenty years of age, nor over twenty five. A good many recruits are being obtained for this grand old regiment

An ex^raord:nary escapade c f three privates of the InniskilUng Dragoons is reported from Ballincollig cavalry barrack9, where the depot is stationed. 8hortly alter midnight on the 25th inst three privates named Donaldson, Duffy, and Liorensoo pooncod npon the sentry when making his rounds, arid, disarming him, proceeded to bind and gag him, after which they left him helpless in a freezing atmosphere. They then entered the stables, and leading three of the best troop,horses ont of the barracks monn+edapff galloped fnrionsly in the direction of Blarney. Meanwhile the unfortunate sentry lay prone on the square unable to stir hand or foot or even skont for assistapoe. For an hoar be remained in this conditiôo. By persistently robbing it against rough and frozen ground, he eventually '"'V managed to remove the gag from his month and his shooting attracted the attsntion of a corporal of the regiment, who about two o'clock in the -morning was retnrning. from Christmas leave. This man fonnd the viotim of the freak almost be combed with the cold and in an exhausted condition. He released him at once and had him attended to at the barraoks. Tbe alarm was immediately raised, and the abeence of the three horses from the stables was no'ioed. A scouring party was organised, and towards morning the three dalinqqeota were met at Carrigrohane Bridge, where they were placed nuder arrest by Corporal Collier.

list.item: It is stated that fhe corporal who ,reaoued the sentry met the three privates on the road Dot fkr from Ballinoollig. rfs they, sped from the barracks and challenged them, bot they disregarded the challenge. A conrt-maTtial will be held into the affair.

div.p: Thia will give the regiment something to talk about. Did the bold dragooDg kiss tha "Blarney Store T" They woold r.qaire that for the cdart-martiah

The Anny Council has under consideration the possibility of reducing tbe présent annual allowance of praotice ball ammunition for trained cavalry and infantry soldiers, Tbe proposal is principally due to representations which have been msde that at some military stations the range «cootemoda' ion is so restricted

list.item: that musketry practice has to be hurried, preventing adequate individual instruction a: d the good, results which should be obtained from praotica, It is suggested to reduce the cavalry and infantry allowance from 300 to 250 rounds. It is snggeated that the ball ammunition now allowed might be used op in praotice by being more snitably spread over the year. The point is one on which meet general offijera commanding agree, and the •Standard" onderstaodia that their opinions on this point will be sent to the War Office.

div.p: The reports of disturbances at Portsmoeth on Christmas Day were gross exaggerations. There was only a stoker who misbehaved by getting drank. Before winding up the day's festivities, the bLarjvskets gathered on tbe square, and sang * God &ave the King."

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
